DOC.HEAD: Snow Falls Across Northern Tier Of States, More Record Lows
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell Monday from Washington state to Maine and winter-like weather threatened the Southeast, and more low temperature records were set across the Midwest. Balmy Miami beckoned with a record high of 87 degrees. Elsewhere, record lows were 1 below zero at Binghamton, N.Y.; 5 below at Cleveland; 3 below at Cincinnati; 7 below at Columbus, Ohio; 3 below at Detroit; 5 below at Fort Wayne, Ind.; 1 below at Lexington, Ky.; 3 below at Mansfield, Ohio; 4 below at Parkersburg, W.Va.; 7 below at Pittsburgh; and 8 below at Youngstown, Ohio. Elsewhere Redding, Calif., hit a record low of 24. At midday, light snow fell from eastern Washington into northwestern Montana and over parts of Idaho, Colorado, South Dakota, Nebraska, Kansas, Missouri, Iowa, Michigan, upstate New York, Vermont and Maine. In the Southeast, bitter cold and slippery roads closed hundreds of schools. Ice was believed to blame for an accident outside Atlanta in which one man was killed. A winter storm warning was posted through the night and into Tuesday over the mountains, foothills and piedmont of South Carolina. Snow and winter weather advisories were in effect into Tuesday for parts of Kentucky, Ohio, North Caroline, and Georgia. New snow accumulations at Colorado ski resorts included 16 inches at Vail, 10 inches at Steamboat, 9{ inches at Breckenridge, and 8 inches at Loveland and Mary Jane, the National Weather Service reported. Steamboat Springs has received 99 inches of snow in nine days, a spokeswoman said. Rain was scattered over central Texas and the upper Texas Gulf Coast, southern Louisiana, southern Mississippi, the Florida Panhandle, northeastern Florida, eastern Georgia and southern South Carolina. Freezing rain extended from central Arkansas across central Louisiana. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 13 degrees below zero at Havre, Mont., to 87 at Miami. Monday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 31 below zero at Warroad, Minn.
